questions.text: A friend of yours has been complaining of a dry cough and asks you to recommend a cough syrup that will not make him drowsy or constipated. Which of the following would be the best option?
questions.solution: Dextromethorphan would be the best option as it is a synthetic central NMDA (N-methyl D-aspartate) receptor antagonist and would be less likely to cause effects like sedation and constipation as seen with opioid antitussives like morphine, hydrocodone, and codeine.

questions.text: What is the duration of cough beyond which a patient is labelled to have 'chronic cough'?
questions.solution:
A cough lasting more than 8 weeks in adults is generally considered chronic cough.

Based on the duration of symptoms, cough is classified as follows:

Description Duration
Acute <3 weeks
Sub-acute 3-8 weeks
Chronic >8 weeks

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with complaints of chronic cough and weight loss. He gives a history of smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily since he was 20 years old. How many pack years has he smoked?
questions.solution:
A standard pack of cigarettes contains 20 cigarettes. The number of pack years smoked is calculated by the formula:

(No. cigarettes smoked per day x No. of years smoked) / 20

This 60-year-old patient has smoked half a pack of cigarettes, ie, 10 cigarettes per day, since the age of 20, ie, for the last 40 years. Therefore, the number of pack years he has smoked would be (10x40) / 20 = 20 pack years

It has been documented that cigarette smoking increases the risk of developing lung cancer 10-fold and cigarette smoking is responsible for as much as 90% of all lung cancers. An accurate history of smoking is essential and should be quantified in a sensitive manner as patients may conceal details. Assessment of smoking history in pack years aids in risk assessment. Current guidelines recommend annual screening for lung cancer with low-dose helical CT in patients aged between 50-80 with a 20-pack-year smoking history who are either current smokers or former smokers having quit within the past 15 years.

questions.text:
Which of the following would be noted in the history of a patient with upper airway cough syndrome?
  1. Expectoration
  2. Post-nasal drip
  3. Sneezing
  4. Rhinorrhoea
  5. Chest pain
questions.solution:
Post-nasal drip, sneezing and rhinorrhea are all features of upper airway cough syndrome whereas expectoration and chest pain are unlikely to be associated with the syndrome.

Inflammation or irritation of the nose and paranasal sinuses usually lead to post-nasal drainage that stimulate the sensory receptors in the pharynx and result in cough. However, it is been observed that patients with chronic inflammation of the nose and paranasal sinuses may have a cough even in the absence of physical drainage into the pharynx and hence the term upper airway cough syndrome is used to describe this spectrum.

Patients may present with cough associated with post-nasal drip, rhinorrhea, sneezing and frequent throat clearing. Examination may reveal inflamed nasal mucosa or polyps, with associated posterior pharyngeal wall congestion.

A history of expectoration and chest pain in association with cough would indicate pathology that is more likely to be distal to the pharynx, ie, affecting the tracheo-bronchial tree or the parenchyma.

questions.text: Which of the following underlying lung pathologies may be indicated by a 'bovine' cough?
questions.solution:
Bovine cough may be indicative of an underlying left hilar malignancy.

A normal cough occurs when the patient expels air against a closed glottis. The term bovine cough refers to a hoarse weak cough that is classically described in patients with a left recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy occurring due to a left hilar malignancy affecting the nerve. This causes vocal cord palsy leading to incomplete closure of the glottis.

questions.text:
Match the following descriptions of sputum characteristics to the most likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with cough with expectoration.
Sputum Characteristic Associated condition
1. Clear, mucoid A. Bronchiectasis
2. Green, purulent B. COPD
3. Rusty, red C. Pulmonary edema
4. Pink, frothy D. Pneumonia
questions.solution:
The correct pairs are as follows:

Sputum Characteristic Associated condition
1. Clear, mucoid B. COPD
2. Green, purulent A. Bronchiectasis
3. Rusty, red D. Pneumonia
4. Pink, frothy C. Pulmonary edema

questions.text: Which of the following would be the most relevant in a hypertensive patient presenting with new onset dry cough?
questions.solution:
In a hypertensive patient with a new onset cough, as the use of an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor should be ruled out as a cause for the cough, and hence medication history would be the most relevant.

Dry cough is a known side effect of ACE inhibitors and occurs due to the accumulation of bradykinins that are normally metabolized by ACE. The incidence of patients on ACE inhibitors developing cough is reported to be as high as 30% and chest x-rays in such patients are likely to have no abnormalities.

Changing the patient's medications from ACE inhibitor to another class of antihypertensives such as angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) would be the best approach to take to treat the patient's cough while still managing the underlying hypertension. In case the patient still has a cough after one month of being put off ACE inhibitors, further workup would be indicated to diagnose the cause of cough.

Other adverse effects of ACE inhibitors include hypotension, angioedema, hyperkalemia, and skin rashes. In patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, it can precipitate acute renal failure.  A rarer complication is visceral angioedema marked by vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. They are also known to be teratogenic and need to be replaced with other drugs during pregnancy.

questions.text: In a patient who presents with a cough, which of the following additional points in history would be most suggestive of lower airway narrowing?
questions.solution:
Wheezing is most likely to be suggestive of lower airway narrowing.

Wheeze is a continuous high-pitched expiratory musical sound produced due to the conduction of sound through a narrow lumen, clinically indicative of lower airway narrowing due to obstruction or inflammation. A patient may complain of a wheeze which is commonly perceived as a whistling note on expiration. However, wheeze is also descriptive of an auscultatory finding of a similar sound. Multiple wheezing sounds heard together are called polyphonic wheeze and are commonly heard in conditions like bronchial asthma, bronchiolitis, and viral infection of the lower respiratory tract. A solitary wheeze or wheeze localized to a single area may indicate a fixed bronchial obstruction.

Other options

Option A: Snoring is caused by oropharyngeal obstruction and is a low-pitched irregular inspiratory sound which points more towards upper airway obstructive pathology.

Option B: Expectoration is more specifically indicative of a collection of secretions within the airways or alveoli, which may lead to airway obstruction, but is not suggestive of luminal narrowing.

Option D: A history of exercise intolerance could indicate underlying pulmonary as well as cardiac pathology, but indicates hypoxia and inadequate gaseous exchange rather than airway obstruction.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents to you with fever and cough with expectoration. On examination, his vitals were as follows: PR- 110/min, RR- 24/min, SpO2- 91%, T- 104 F. His radiograph is as shown below. Which of the following findings would be seen on clinical examination of his respiratory system?

choices.text: Vesicular breath sounds, increased vocal resonance and tactile fremitus
Bronchial breath sounds, increased vocal resonance and tactile fremitus
Vesicular breath sounds, decreased vocal resonance and tactile fremitus
Bronchial breath sounds, decreased vocal resonance and tactile fremitus

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and chest x-ray showing a consolidation in the right lower lobe is suggestive of a likely diagnosis of pneumonia. The patient is likely to have bronchial breath sounds with increased vocal resonance and tactile fremitus.

In a healthy lung, the sound of air passing through the airways gets muffled as it goes from the upper airways with a wide luminal cross-section to the lower-airways with a narrower luminal cross-section. This produces the 'normal vesicular' breath sounds heard on auscultation. In a consolidated or fibrosed lung, which becomes more dense than air-filled, the sound of air in the distal airways getting better conducted through the diseased lung parenchyma. As a result, on auscultation, a louder sound is heard, similar to what would be heard in the bronchi or proximal airways, hence the term 'bronchial' breath sounds is used.

The same principle applies to the conduction of vocally produced sound, ie, normally it is muffled in a healthy lung but it is better conducted in a consolidated lung and hence the patient also has an increased vocal resonance and increased tactile vocal fremitus.

Breath sounds and vocal resonance would both be decreased in conditions where the conduction of air through the chest wall is impaired, such as due to the presence of air or fluid as in pneumothorax and pleural effusion respectively, or in the case of a collapsed lung.

questions.text: While crossing the road, a truck with dense exhaust fumes pass you by and you immediately cough. Which of the following receives sensory stimuli for the generation of the reflex involved?
questions.solution:
The nucleus tractus solitarius received the sensory afferents in the cough reflex.

The cough reflex is a protective mechanism of the larynx to expel irritants and keep the airway clear. Chemical or mechanical irritation of the respiratory mucosa stimulates the afferent internal laryngeal nerve, which is the branch of the superior laryngeal nerve of the vagus nerve. These sensory fibres synapse in the nucleus tractus solitarius in the medulla oblongata. Complex neural networks here generate the conscious 'urge to cough' while also sending efferent signals to the various muscles involved in generating an effective cough which include the adductors of the vocal cord, the diaphragm, the external intercostals and the muscles of the anterior abdominal wall.

Alcohol can cause chemical irritation of the internal laryngeal nerve while also acting as a potent inhibitor of the central nervous system, which may cause inhibition of the cough and gag reflexes that increase the risk of aspiration.

Other options:

Option B: The nucleus ambiguus sends motor efferent fibres to the pharyngeal constrictors, intrinsic laryngeal muscles, and striated muscles of the palate and upper esophagus through the CN IX and CN X.

Option C: The inferior salivatory nucleus give rise to the preganglionic parasympathetic fibres that enter that relay in the otic ganglion, as part of the secretomotor pathway of the parotid gland.

Option D: The rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) is the major excitatory source of the sympathetic nervous system that forms part of the baroreceptor reflex, responsible for causing a rise in BP.

questions.text:
Which of the following are unlikely to be seen in cough-variant asthma?
  1. Wheezing
  2. Shortness of breath
  3. Chest tightness
  4. Reversal of symptoms with bronchodilator
  5. Positive methacholine challenge
questions.solution:
Cough-variant asthma refers to the atypical presentation of asthma where a patient presents with cough in the absence of typical features like wheeze, shortness of breath, and chest tightness.

The cough develops in the presence of environmental triggers such as allergens, cold weather, exercise etc. Such patients are diagnosed by objective tests for asthma such as the methacholine challenge test, and their symptoms improve with the use of bronchodilators. This kind of presentation is more common among children.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with incomplete vaccination history comes with vomiting after bouts of severe, violent cough. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an unimmunized child with a violent cough and post-tussive vomiting is suggestive of pertussis (whooping cough) which is caused by Bordetella pertussis.

The organism Bordetella pertussis is a gram-negative coccobacillus. The major virulence factor is the Pertussis toxin which acts by ADP ribosylation of the inhibitory G-protein (Gi) and the Filamentous haemagglutinin (FHA) is responsible for facilitating the adhesion of Bordetella pertussis to the respiratory epithelium.  Following an incubation period of about 2 weeks, the disease clinically presents over 3 phases :

Catarrhal - lasts for 1-2 weeks and consists of cough, coryza, and nasopharyngeal secretions.
Paroxysmal - lasts for 2-6 weeks and consists of worsening paroxysms of productive whooping cough. It becomes more frequent and is commonly associated with vomiting at the end of the bout. Whooping cough derives its name from the inspiratory whoop at the end of a coughing bout. 
Convalescent - Intensity and frequency of cough decrease over 4 weeks.

The diagnosis is made on clinical grounds. A specific diagnosis can be made by isolation of the organism from a nasopharyngeal swab taken in the first two phases. Bordetella pertussis shows colonies resembling 'bisected pearls' or 'mercury drops' on Bordet-Gengou medium.  


Management involves antibiotic therapy and supportive care.

The incidence of pertussis has decreased significantly after widespread immunization. Pertussis vaccine is usually administered in combination with toxoids of diphtheria and tetanus as the DPT or DTaP vaccines. As per the national immunization schedule in India, children are vaccinated against pertussis with the pentavalent vaccine which is administered at 6, 10 and 14 weeks of age. The inactivated pertussis toxin (PT) is the key immunogenic component.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presented with low-grade fever, biphasic stridor, and a barking cough. The following was noted on X-ray. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of laryngotracheobronchitis which is caused by Parainfluenza.

Laryngotracheobronchitis, also known as croup, is usually seen in children aged 6 months to 3 years. Children with croup present with a barking cough, biphasic stridor, and low-grade fever.  Chest x-ray shows a steeple sign due to subglottic narrowing.

Management:

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the improvement of upper airway obstruction. 
  • Dexamethasone, by the least invasive route (Oral>IV>IM ), is indicated in all the grades of croup.
  • Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %)

Antibiotics are usually not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.

Other options:

Option A: Moraxella causes acute otitis media. Children present with otalgia, fever, crying, and irritability.

Option B: Haemophilus influenza causes acute epiglottitis. Children present with an acute sore throat, high fever, muffled voice, inspiratory stridor, marked dysphagia, and drooling.

Option D: Staphylococcus aureus causes tracheitis. Children present with a history of croup, brassy cough, and expiratory or biphasic stridor. X-ray neck shows an irregular tracheal wall.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought with a history of cough for two months that has not responded to any kind of treatment and relevant investigations have all returned normal. The mother says that the child coughs loudly and abruptly but with no change in facial appearance or any other associated symptoms, and he does not cough when he is watching TV or sleeping. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of chronic cough in a child, which is refractory to treatment, with no associated symptoms and not occurring when the child is asleep or distracted is suggestive of tic cough.

Tic cough, also known as somatic cough disorder, habit cough or psychogenic cough, is a behavioural abnormality in the paediatric population that is not associated with any pathology of the respiratory system. The child may begin coughing due to a URTI but continues to do so as a habit even after the infection has subsided. It is characterised by intense loud, abrupt coughing that does not match the child's affect. The cough is generally absent during sleep or periods of distraction. The frequency of the cough may cause the child to miss school and may lead to several medical investigations.

Behavioural and speech therapy are indicated for the management and the parents are to be reassured that there is no underlying pathology of concern and that the child may resume all normal activities.

Other options:

Option A: Common cold due to a viral infection is likely to be associated with symptoms such as sneezing, rhinorrhea and possibly systemic signs like fever and malaise.

Option B: Cough due to a foreign body is likely to be acute rather than chronic, and the presence of a foreign body is likely to be ruled out with preliminary investigations in a child. In this case, all investigations returned normal.

Option D: Cough due to adenoid hypertrophy is likely to be associated with grunting and exacerbation during sleep, along with other typical symptoms like adenoid facies and voice change.

questions.text: A 60 year old male patient presents with complaints of cough and breathlessness since 2 weeks. History of which of the following would be most helpful in considering a cardiac pathology?
questions.solution:
Paroxysmal Nocturnal Dyspnea (PND) in a patient with complaints of cough and breathlessness is highly suggestive of underlying cardiac pathology, specifically congestive cardiac failure.

In a patient with congestive cardiac failure, left ventricular dysfunction causes a build-up of back pressures in the pulmonary vasculature leading to pulmonary congestion. When a patient lies down, the venous return increases which worsens the pulmonary congestion. This leads to orthopnea, ie, exacerbation of dyspnea on lying down, and PND, where a patient becomes breathlessness a few hours after going to sleep and wakes up and hangs their legs down by the side of the bed or stands up and walks to the window for relief of symptoms. PND is unlikely to be associated with a pulmonary pathology alone in the absence of a cardiac pathology.

Patients with congestive cardiac failure with pulmonary edema may also have wheezing and expectoration (options A and C) but these symptoms in the absence of PND may point towards several respiratory causes such as asthma, COPD, interstitial lung disease etc and is not specific to cardiac disease. Cyanosis (option D) refers to the bluish discolouration of the skin or mucous membranes which occurs in hypoxic conditions when the deoxyhaemoglobin concentration exceeds 5g/dL. It may also been seen in either pulmonary or cardiac disease.

Related Pearl: Summary of Pathogenesis of Major Findings in Congestive Heart Failure

Summary of Pathogenesis of Major Findings in Congestive Heart Failure

Abnormality

Cause

Left ventricle output inadequate to perfuse muscles; especially, failure of output to rise with exercise

Ankle, sacral edema

Increased peripheral venous pressure →increased fluid transudation.

Hepatomegaly

Increased peripheral venous pressure →increased resistance to portal flow.

Increased pulmonary venous pressure →pulmonary venous distention and transudation of fluid into air spaces

Failure of left ventricular output to rise during exercise → increased pulmonary venous pressure

Probably a sudden failure of left heart output to keep up with the right heart output →acute rise in pulmonary venous and capillary pressure →transudation of fluid into air spaces.

Orthopnea

Greater ventricular end-diastolic volume.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions would a patient be least likely to complain of a cough?
questions.solution:
Patients with vocal nodules are unlikely to present with a cough. Patients complain of complain of hoarseness, vocal fatigue, and neck pain during prolonged talking.

Vocal nodules (Singer's or Screamer's nodes) are benign nodules arising from the free edge of the vocal cord at the junction between anterior one-third and posterior two-third of the vocal cord which are mostly symmetrical (bilateral). It most commonly affects teachers, actors, singers, vendors, and talkative school children.


Cough may be a symptom in several extra-pulmonary conditions. GERD, cardiac failure and sinusitis are all examples of extra-pulmonary conditions where cough is a common associated symptom.

questions.text: A 14-day-old neonate with bilateral conjunctivitis is found to have pulmonary infiltrates on chest X-ray. Which of the following is likely to be observed in the patient?
questions.solution:
Bilateral conjunctivitis followed by pneumonia in a neonate is suggestive of infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. Infantile pneumonia due to C. trachomatis is typically associated with a staccato cough, which refers to paroxysmal cough associated with an inspiratory breath between each cough.

Chlamydia trachomatis inclusion conjunctivitis usually manifests 1 week after birth. It is usually a venereal infection derived from the cervix or urethra of the mother during delivery. If left untreated, associated systemic diseases such as chlamydial otitis and pneumonia may develop later.

Other options:

Option B: Whooping cough is seen in pertussis, caused by Bordetella pertussis. It is characterized by a continuous bout of coughing at the end of which the child takes a deep breath which makes a 'whooping' sound.

Option C: Bovine cough refers to a hoarse weak cough that is classically described in patients with a left recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, causing vocal cord palsy resulting in an incomplete closure of the glottis. 

Option D: Barking cough, likened to the sound of a seal's bark is typically associated with croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) and epiglotittis.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be associated with an impaired cough response?
questions.solution:
Chronic bronchitis is characterized by chronic cough with expectoration and is unlikely to be associated with an impaired cough.

Chronic bronchitis is a form of COPD, characterized by hyperplasia and hypersecretion of the mucous glands, due to insult by tobacco smoke or air pollutants, mostly in the bronchus and presents with persistent cough and sputum production for 3 months, in at least 2 consecutive years, without any other identifiable cause.

Cough is not always pathological and performs an important protective function in preventing the entry of irritants and clearing the airways of collections. Impaired cough may be a predisposing factor for the development of respiratory diseases such as infections and collapse due to the retention of airway secretions or aspirated material. Impaired cough is most commonly associated with weakness of the respiratory or abdominal muscles, which leads to the inability to generate adequate velocity to clear airway collections. Other causes of impaired cough include:

  • Chest or abdominal pain (eg. post-operative)
  • Chest wall deformities (eg. kyphoscoliosis)
  • Respiratory depression (eg. due to anesthesia/drugs/neurological disease)
  • Abnormal airway secretions (eg. cystic fibrosis)
  • Structural airway disease (eg. tracheomalacia, tracheal stenosis)
  • Ciliary dysfunction (eg. ciliary dysfunction)
  • Bronchiectasis

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with a cough impulse?
questions.solution:
Cough impulse is not seen in primary hydrocele.

Cough impulse refers to the impulse felt on palpation of a swelling, either as a thrill, as seen in (varicocele, lymph varix) or an expansile impulse where the swelling increases in size when a patient is asked to cough, which is otherwise not normally felt. Cough impulse is a positive clinical finding in swellings that are in continuity with the abdominal (eg - inguinal hernia), pleural (eg - empyema necessitans), or cranial cavities and spinal canal (eg - meningocele) as coughing increases the pressure in that compartment which is represented by the impulse. 

Hydrocoele is an accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis. In the case of a primary hydrocoele, as the fluid is collected within a closed sac, a cough impulse is unlikely to be seen. However, in the case of a congenital hydrocoele due to the presence of a patent processus vaginalis, a cough impulse may be positive as a thrill. Important positive clinical findings in a hydrocoele are that they are irreducible,  the testes cannot be palpated separately, ability to get above the swelling, and transillumination of the swelling.

Other options:

Option A: Saphena varix refers to the saccular enlargement of the termination of the long saphenous vein at the saphenous opening. A cough impulse is felt in a saphena varix is called a positive Morrissey's test and indicates sapheno-femoral incompetence.

Option B: Empyema necessitans is a known complication of empyema wherein undrained pus in the pleural cavity incites an inflammatory response that leads to sinus formation causing the pus to track from the pleural cavity to the chest wall, leading to findings of boggy chest wall that may have a swelling with cough impulse, and intercostal tenderness.

Option D: Meningocele is a neural tube defect presenting as a sacral swelling that may be associated with a tuft of hair. Increased intra-abdominal pressure from coughing is transmitted to the CSF leading to a cough impulse as the swelling is in communication with the sub-arachnoid space.

questions.text: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to?
questions.solution:
Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold's nerve).

Arnold's nerve supplies the concha and corresponding eminence on the medial surface. It also supplies the posterior wall and floor of the external auditory canal. Scratching or mechanical stimulation of the ear leads to activation of Arnold's nerve, which evokes reflex cough (ear-cough reflex/otorespiratory reflex).

Temporomandibular joint and dental conditions, parotid infections/tumor, and anterior 2/3rd of tongue Auriculotemporal nerve Tragal area, crus of the helix, and anterior wall and roof of the external auditory canal. 
Acute tonsillitis, peritonsillar abscess, carcinoma base of the tongue or tonsils (oropharynx) The glossopharyngeal nerve (Jacobson's) Medial surface of the tympanic membrane, and middle ear
Carcinoma of the larynx (cough), hypopharynx, epiglottis, vallecula, esophagus, and thyroid Auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold's/Alderman's nerve) Concha, posterior wall, and floor of the external auditory canal
Cervical spondylitis Great auricular nerve (C2,3) Lateral and medial surfaces of the pinna
Acoustic neuroma Facial nerve (nervus intermedius/nerve of Wrisberg)

Concha, retro auricular groove, and posterosuperior part of the external auditory meatus. Numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall known as Hitzelberger's sign, is seen in acoustic neuroma.
